Its called 'over centered' - the terminology for the mechanism that locks a vice grip.  Its a 4 bar mechanism, sized so the action can be forced 'over a center point', and against a stop, relying on the elasticity of the material to keep it in position.  When you adjust a vice grip, you are adjusting the length of one of the links.  Three of the links are in the tool.  The fourth is the object you are trying to clamp.

I've seen lots of people say that because we're copying things from nature, evolution cannot be true.

Well, let me say this: Evolution's got a head-start on humanity of about 3.6 billion years. Lots of time for it to come up with incredibly good designs.

Second, evolution is not chaos. It's different. It's random mutations where the bad ones are (usually brutally) beaten out of the system and the beneficial ones last a lot longer. Ones which have no effect generally just... stick around.

Now, evolution IS slow, but as I said, 3.6 billion years. That's a long time even on a cosmological scale. That is 3.6 billion years of the bad stuff being kicked out and the useful stuff being kept and constantly refined. THAT'S why there's so many systems in biology we cannot replicate and haven't come up with. Nor are we at the limit of our technology. We're improving, and one day we'll end up surpassing nature in nearly every respect (if we live that long).

Saying it disproves evolution isn't a good argument, it's a wilful admission that you don't have a clue about what you're arguing against.

Also, we've done a number of experiments that have proven that evolution exists. If you dismiss that as God testing us, I'm not interested, because that's the worst cop-out I've heard.

The experiments? There's two I can think of off the top of my head: In TWO MONTHS, researchers created multicellular yeast by doing nothing but selecting for heavier samples (removing the lightest ones and letting the heaviest grow) and the E. Coli long-term evolutionary experiment.

That's not taking into account all the lifeforms evolving resistances to things like pesticides, herbicides, antibacterials...

Please answer this: I am having a difficult time understanding how evolution creates such things such as this Mantis Shrimp. I was a firm believer in evolution. I was. Neil deGrasse Tyson or any other scientists, theorists, etc. all say that its the result of "millions of years of evolution". Even with millions of years and "tiny mutations over time of trial and error", it still doesn't stand to reason. I am grappling with how this "evolution" happens. I've seen a documentary (“What Plants Talk About”) that when Tobacco plants are attacked and eaten by bugs, the plant then releases a chemical that attracts the predator of that particular bug. So the plant saves itself by calling for help. How is that possible? How does the plant even "sense" what chemicals bugs put off? It has no chemical receptors. It has no brain. It has no nervous system. And how does it keep up with the chemical changes in other bug species. How does it know that a particular bug eats another bug? And please don't say "Time" and "mutations" or "God". Thank you.

Great video as always Destin. Peacock mantis shrimp are one of my favorite animals so it was nice getting some slow motion footage of their amazing strike.

One small correction to something you said in the video though, mantis shrimp don't actually see more colors than other animals, their color distinction actually turns out to be worse than other animals.

As per a paper published Nov 19 2013 in science magazine
"Color vision is generally carried out through the number of photoreceptor types found in the retina. The mantis shrimps (stomatopods) can have up to 12 photoreceptors, far more than needed for even extreme color acuity. Thoen et al. (p. 411; see the Perspective by Land and Osorio) conducted paired color discrimination tests with stomatopods and found that their ability to discriminate among colors was surprisingly low. Instead, stomatopods appear to use a color identification approach that results from a temporal scan of an object across the 12 photoreceptor sensitivities. This entirely unique form of vision would allow for extremely rapid color recognition without the need to discriminate between wavelengths within a spectrum"

http://www.sciencemag.org/content/343/6169/411

The storing of energy in elastic structures is fairly well known in both animals and plants.  Downunder, the kangaroos use that trick -- storing energy in flexible tendons.  In the plant world, jewelweed (Impatiens capensis) sends its seeds flying when the pods are brushed.

What impresses me the most is the unique composite.  Hopefully, it will be yet another example of ideas from nature being used in engineering.  It would be difficult to manufacture now, but 3D printers might be used in the future.  To ramp it up another notch, the composite can be reinforced with carbon nanotubes.

By the way, I would love to see some high speed video of a jewelweed seed pod exploding.  The plant is common around here (Michigan,) but I don't know how far south it ranges.

While they have way more different color receptors than we do, they apparently can't fine-gradedly differentiate between them.
